title: Finding Ancient Genes from Before All Life
summary: Scientists have discovered special genes called universal paralogs that existed before all life on Earth. Every living thing today comes from a single ancestor that lived billions of years ago, called the last universal common ancestor. These universal paralogs are genes that appear in almost all organisms, like in humans and plants. They were copied from older genes before the first common ancestor existed. Researchers studied these genes to learn about early life. They found that these ancient genes helped with making proteins and moving things in and out of cells. This tells us that protein production and membrane transport were some of the first jobs cells had. Scientists use computers and AI to study these genes more easily. By looking at universal paralogs, we can understand how life started and evolved long ago.

background_read: Life on Earth began billions of years ago from a single ancestor called the last universal common ancestor. Scientists study genes to learn about early life. Universal paralogs are special genes that existed before this ancestor and are found in almost all organisms today. They help with basic cell functions like making proteins and moving molecules. Researchers use technology like AI to analyze these genes and uncover clues about how life evolved from simple beginnings.
Article_Structure: WHO: Scientists like Aaron Goldman, Greg Fournier, and Betül Kaçar
WHAT: They discovered universal paralogs, genes that existed before all life and help understand early cell functions
WHERE: In research published in journals and at universities like Oberlin College and MIT
WHY: To learn how life started and evolved by studying ancient genes
